dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the economy totally crashed after COVID, right? We're still, uh, in a mess, I think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the economy totally crashed after COVID, right? We're still, uh, in a mess, I think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made. The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, no, not at all, Host_A. The US economy, um, has really achieved something called a "soft landing." It's actually been pretty extraordinary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, no, not at all, Host_A. The U S economy, um, has really achieved something called a soft landing. It's actually been pretty extraordinary.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made. The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? I thought it was all doom and gloom. How'd we, like, even get there, though?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? I thought it was all doom and gloom. How'd we, like, even get there, though?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, initially, during the pandemic, the big challenge was keeping people's incomes up, you know, with all the lockdowns and supply issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, initially, during the pandemic, the big challenge was keeping people's incomes up, you know, with all the lockdowns and supply issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immediate challenge was to maintain consumers incomes in the face of sweeping lockdowns, supply-chain disruptions, and shifts in aggregate supply.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that makes sense. But then, uh, I heard something about people buying, like, more stuff? Not, like, going out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that makes sense. But then, uh, I heard something about people buying, like, more stuff? Not, like, going out?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! There was a huge structural shift. Everyone started buying durable goods – things like, um, appliances or electronics – because we were all stuck at home. Services, like restaurants, dropped off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! There was a huge structural shift. Everyone started buying durable goods - things like, um, appliances or electronics - because we were all stuck at home. Services, like restaurants, dropped off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge concerned a broader crisis-induced structural shift away from the purchase of services especially in-person services toward the purchase of durable goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, less going out, more Amazon. Got it. And, uh, that "Buy American" thing helped with that, too?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, less going out, more Amazon. Got it. And, uh, that Buy American thing helped with that, too?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, that initiative kinda turbo-charged the durable goods trend. It meant we needed to shift workers and industries to meet that new demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, that initiative kinda turbo-charged the durable goods trend. It meant we needed to shift workers and industries to meet that new demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, didn't that cause, like, inflation? And what about jobs, weren't people supposed to lose jobs in services?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, didn't that cause, like, inflation? And what about jobs, weren't people supposed to lose jobs in services?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It did mean some inflation, yes, especially in those expanding sectors. Wages and prices in shrinking services, they're "sticky," so they don't just fall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It did mean some inflation, yes, especially in those expanding sectors. Wages and prices in shrinking services, they're sticky, so they don't just fall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, creating more supply in the areas where there was growing demand required wage and price inflation in the newly expanding sectors. ... Since neither nominal wages nor prices were going to fall back to their previous levels (they are sticky, in the economic parlance), substantially cutting wages and prices in shrinking service-sector industries was a non-starter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sticky? Like, they don't go down easily?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sticky? Like, they don't go down easily?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. So, the solution was reskilling workers, uh, redirecting labor to new, growing areas, like tech and renewable energy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. So, the solution was reskilling workers, uh, redirecting labor to new, growing areas, like tech and renewable energy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the government helped people get new jobs? And the Fed, weren't they, like, worried about a recession when they raised rates?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the government helped people get new jobs? And the Fed, weren't they, like, worried about a recession when they raised rates?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, many people were. The Fed, under Chairwoman Yellen, actually navigated it with remarkable precision. We didn't get that recession.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, many people were. The Fed, under Chairwoman Yellen, actually navigated it with remarkable precision. We didn't get that recession.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the US Federal Reserve began its rapid tightening cycle in the spring of 2022, I was constantly worried that it would go too far and send the US economy into an unnecessary and avoidable recession. ... But there has been no recession

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, uh, everything's better than we thought? Like, the numbers are good now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, uh, everything's better than we thought? Like, the numbers are good now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Even better! Recent data revisions show income growth post-pandemic was substantially higher. And productivity? It's been revised up too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even better! Recent data revisions show income growth post-pandemic was substantially higher. And productivity? It's been revised up too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, we also recently learned, following data revisions, that income growth coming out of the pandemic was substantially higher than previously estimated. ... This means that estimated productivity growth since the start of 2020 will be revised upward by about 0.3 percentage points per year

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, uh, no more worries then? No clouds on the horizon?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, uh, no more worries then? No clouds on the horizon?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, there are always potential risks, like, um, the AI boom turning out to be a bubble. Or job displacement from automation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, there are always potential risks, like, um, the A I boom turning out to be a bubble. Or job displacement from automation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One obvious risk is that the ongoing AI boom will prove to be a bubble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like that's a big one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like that's a big one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But for now, we should really just, uh, appreciate this soft landing. It's been quite the recovery, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But for now, we should really just, uh, appreciate this soft landing. It's been quite the recovery, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made. The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.
